title: Travel company launches rare train tours through North Korea with stops in undiscovered industrial cities
text:
View
comments
A travel company that specialises in tours to North Korea is offering adventurous holidaymakers the chance to see the secretive country in a way very few people have before.
Beijing-based Koryo Tours is selling seats on a train tour that will take visitors from the capital of Pyongyang to Mount Myohyang and along the rarely-visited east and north-east coast to the industrial city of Chongjin.
Tourists will spend a week and a half travelling through the North Korean countryside with assigned guides and become some of the first foreigners to take in the scenery between Pyongyang and the north-east region, which was previously only accessible by a special charter flight.
Beijing-based Koryo Tours is offering a train tour that will take visitors through North Korea's countryside
The tour will take foreigners along the rarely-visited east and north-east coast to the industrial city of Chongjin
The 10-night tour costs €2,890 (£2,050 or $3,200), including return flights from Beijing and hotels
Holidaymakers will enjoy views of mountains, rolling hills and pristine coasts, and stop in undiscovered cities such as Sinpho and Kimchaek when the 10-night tour is held in October.
At a cost of €2,890 (£2,050 or $3,200) per person, including flights and hotels, the tour group will travel in vintage 1970s carriages with diesel locomotives and a fully-functioning restaurant car.

In Pyongyang the group will see all of the major sights, including the Arch of Triumph, which commemorates the country’s independence from Japan, and the Victorious Fatherland Liberation War Museum.
The trip includes two journeys from Pyongyang - one to Mount Myohyang and the other to Chongjin
October's group of tourists will be one of the first to travel overnight by train within North Korea
The tour group will travel in vintage 1970s carriages with diesel locomotives and a restaurant car
When they visit Hamhung, North Korea’s second-largest city, holidaymakers will tour a fertilizer factory to get a glimpse into socialist heavy industry.
In Chongjin they will visit a school, where local children will perform a musical routine, a foodstuffs factory, and a statue of former leader Kim Il Sung.
According to Koryo Tours, the air around Mount Myohyang – known as the Mountain of Mysterious Fragrance – is said to be so fresh that people won’t wake up with a hangover after a night of drinking.
Simon Cockerell, general manager of Koryo Tours, said this journey will include more unseen places than the inaugural tour last year.
He told CNN : ‘It'll be the first time we have a train ride between Pyongyang and Mountain Myohyang. It'll also be the first time we will be taking a local tram ride in Chongjin.’
Tourists will spend a week and a half travelling through the North Korean countryside with assigned guides
North Korea only recently began allowing foreign tourists to go on domestic train journeys
